etymologies: mid 17th century: from French, or from Latin contractura, from Latin contract- ‘drawn together’, from the verb contrahere

definitions: a condition of shortening and hardening of muscles, tendons, or other tissue, often leading to deformity and rigidity of joints

examples.text: contracture of the hip in cerebral palsy
the contractures had been caused by intramuscular injections

shortDefinitions: condition of shortening and hardening of tissue, often leading to deformity and rigidity of joints
